content: @T-release meeting!
@DPC -- triage checkin?
nothing much to report. had a routine monthly meeting on wed with the team.
okay, great. moving on -- we have a release next week
I believe @Pietro Albini is running it?
yeah
that should be it
I just r+'d the last round of backports, and touched base with Steve -- we should have a draft for the blog sometime today, I think
So I think we should be good to go
Anyone have something else to bring up?
toolstate is broken, but i think the team is working on fixing it (Rls + rustfmt)
Maybe the Linux platform support? Not sure who needs to weigh in on that. (Dropping RHEL5)
Okay -- I'll try and ping some folks after the meeting wrt to toolstate to confirm that it's on its way to being fixed
@cuviper I'm not sure. Maybe we should just FCP it for release team?
Anyone have thoughts on how we should approve that change?
Do you want an issue on the release team repo for that?
hm I don't think so, or at least not sure we'd get much out of that
I was going to directly FCP the PR
Ok
I'll do that after the meeting, and if folks feel that we should be doing something different, feel free to raise a concern, I'm definitely open to alternatives as well
Anything else?
I think it would also help to document how we'll decide this in the future. Right now it's basically that Red Hat and SUSE stakeholders agree on this baseline.
Maybe that's enough, but we could make that clear.

It seems reasonable to say that basically we try to provide a baseline of support that works for downstream distros, though I would maybe not restrict the set just to Red Hat and SUSE -- though we could make it so that we check in with both by default at least
Maybe a PR against the platform support page on forge or something could work, or just an informal document in the release team repo
(I guess we could approve an RFC to that effect)
Those two just have the longest support requirements, that's all.
In the short term I'll fcp the PR, but I agree it would be good to formalize the constraints here. I think an RFC could be a good fit for doing so -- I might try and find time to sketch a draft
(or if you want to @cuviper, that'd be amazing!)
I can take that on
Let's call the meeting here then. Thanks all!
